evidence: Rockmore studied with Theremin after meeting him in New York; they collaborated on improving the instrument's range and responsiveness.
Cage frequently cited Satie as a major influence, particularly his furniture music concept. Cage organized Satie festivals and performed his work.
Young encountered Cage's ideas through the Darmstadt summer courses and correspondence; Cage's chance operations influenced Young's early work.
Bayle studied at GRM under Schaeffer, eventually succeeding him as director in 1966.
Bayle studied with Stockhausen in addition to his work at GRM.
Ciani developed close working relationship with Buchla, becoming primary demonstrator and advocate for his instruments.
Carlos worked extensively with Moog developing the synthesizer, providing feedback that shaped instrument design. Their collaboration produced Switched-On Bach.
Deutsch collaborated with Moog on the initial development of the Moog synthesizer, providing the composer's perspective on interface design.
Hassell performed with La Monte Young's Theatre of Eternal Music and studied his ideas about sustained tones and just intonation.
Riley and Young were close collaborators in San Francisco and New York, developing ideas about repetition, drones, and extended duration together.
Reich and Glass performed in each other's ensembles during the formative period of minimalism in New York.
Conrad was member of La Monte Young's Theatre of Eternal Music, performing extended drone works on violin.
Russolo's Art of Noises manifesto directly influenced Cage's expansion of music to include all sounds.
Feldman and Cage were close friends and mutual influences; Feldman's quiet dynamics and duration experiments developed in dialogue with Cage's ideas.
Eno frequently cites Cage as fundamental influence. Cage's ideas about ambient sound, silence, and environmental music directly shaped Eno's ambient philosophy.
Tudor was premiere performer of Cage's works, including the first performance of 4'33". They collaborated throughout their careers.
Oliveros acknowledged Cage's influence on her thinking about listening and environmental sound, though she developed distinct approaches.
Eno explicitly cited Satie's furniture music as direct precursor to ambient music in liner notes for Music for Airports.
Schaeffer and Henry co-founded musique concrète, collaborating on foundational works including Symphonie pour un homme seul.
Stockhausen worked at Schaeffer's GRM studio in Paris in 1952, learning musique concrète techniques before developing his own electronic music approach.
Eno's tape manipulation techniques and treatment of recorded sound as compositional material derive from musique concrète tradition initiated by Schaeffer.
Young's drone work and exploration of extended duration directly influenced Eno's ambient concepts.
Young and Riley developed minimalist ideas together in San Francisco; Young's drone concepts influenced Riley's repetitive structures.
A Rainbow in Curved Air directly influenced German electronic musicians including Tangerine Dream's keyboard-based improvisations.
Riley's tape loop and repetition techniques directly influenced Eno's early ambient work.
Reich's phasing and process music techniques influenced Eno's approach to gradual change in ambient works.
Schulze was founding member of Tangerine Dream, playing drums on Electronic Meditation before departing.
Schnitzler was founding member of Tangerine Dream, appearing on Electronic Meditation.
Franke was member of Tangerine Dream during their most influential period, helping develop their sequencer-based sound.
Baumann was key member during TD's classic Phaedra and Rubycon period.
Roedelius and Moebius co-founded Kluster (later Cluster) with Conrad Schnitzler, continuing as duo after Schnitzler's departure.
The three co-founded Kluster; Schnitzler departed 1971 to pursue solo work.
Co-founding members of Kluster.
Roedelius, Moebius, and Rother formed Harmonia, combining Cluster's textures with Rother's guitar work.
Co-founding members of Harmonia.
Rother and Dinger co-founded Neu! after both briefly played with Kraftwerk, inventing the motorik sound.
Schulze was founding drummer of Ash Ra Tempel with Göttsching before departing for solo career.
Co-founded Kraftwerk, leading the group together for decades.
Stockhausen's electronic experiments at WDR Cologne influenced Kraftwerk's approach to electronic composition.
Stockhausen's spatial and electronic experiments influenced Tangerine Dream's approach to synthesizers and immersive sound.
Plank produced Kraftwerk's first three albums before they built their own Kling Klang studio.
Plank produced key Cluster albums including Zuckerzeit and Sowiesoso, shaping their sound.
Plank produced all three Neu! albums, crucial to their distinctive sound.
Plank produced both Harmonia albums.
Plank facilitated Eno's collaborations with German artists, co-producing Cluster & Eno albums at his studio.
Eno and Fripp created foundational ambient works (No Pussyfooting) (1973) and Evening Star (1975) using tape loop techniques (Frippertronics).
Eno produced The Pavilion of Dreams (1978), Ambient 2: The Plateaux of Mirror (1980), and The Pearl (1984), defining Budd's mature sound.
Beyond production, Plateaux of Mirror and The Pearl are credited as collaborations.
Eno discovered Laraaji busking in Washington Square Park and produced Ambient 3: Day of Radiance (1980).
Lanois became Eno's primary collaborator from early 1980s, co-producing Apollo, The Pearl, and many subsequent works.
Brothers; collaborated on Apollo: Atmospheres & Soundtracks (1983) and later works.
Collaborated on Apollo and subsequent albums including Mixing Colours (2020).
Eno collaborated with Cluster on Cluster & Eno (1977) and After the Heat (1978), visiting their studio in Forst.
Co-created Cluster & Eno and After the Heat albums.
Eno visited Harmonia's studio in Forst (1976), recording sessions released decades later as Tracks and Traces (1997/2009).
Eno released Bryars' The Sinking of the Titanic and Jesus' Blood Never Failed Me Yet on his Obscure Records label.
Eno released Nyman's Decay Music on Obscure Records.
Collaborated on Fourth World Vol. 1: Possible Musics (1980), pioneering fusion of ambient and world music.
Bryars and Nyman were part of the same experimental music scene in London; both released on Obscure Records.
Both pioneered dub independently but were aware of each other's work in Kingston's studio scene; King Tubby's mixing innovations influenced the broader approach.
Eno cited dub as influence on his studio-as-instrument approach, particularly the emphasis on spatial manipulation and remix.
Perry's experimental production techniques at Black Ark studio influenced Eno's approach to found sound and unconventional studio methods.
Moog began building theremins as a teenager, inspired by Theremin's instrument. This sparked his interest in electronic instruments that led to the synthesizer.
Tangerine Dream were major users of Moog synthesizers; the Minimoog defined much of their sound.
Schulze was prolific user of Moog synthesizers throughout his career.
Co-founded EMS (Electronic Music Studios), with Cockerell designing the VCS3 circuitry.
Cary was co-founder of EMS.
Co-founders of EMS.
Eno extensively used EMS synthesizers (VCS3, Synthi AKS) during Roxy Music and early solo career; the instruments shaped his sound.
Derbyshire used EMS equipment and was part of the British electronic music scene connected to EMS.
Ciani became primary Buchla demonstrator and advocate; worked closely with Buchla on instrument development and demonstration.
Buchla instruments were developed in dialogue with SFTMC composers including Oliveros.
Scott and Moog exchanged ideas about electronic instrument design; both were working on similar problems independently.
Both worked on Doctor Who music; Cary contributed to the series while Derbyshire created the famous theme realization.
Derbyshire's tape manipulation work and atmospheric compositions at the Radiophonic Workshop prefigured and influenced British ambient/electronic music including Eno's approach.
Co-founded Yellow Magic Orchestra with Yukihiro Takahashi.
Both part of the Japanese kankyō ongaku (environmental music) scene in the 1980s; contemporaries working in similar directions.
Yoshimura's environmental music was influenced by Eno's ambient music concepts, though developed distinctly for Japanese contexts.
Close friends and mutual influences; both members of the New York School of composers.
Feldman's extremely quiet dynamics and long-duration works influenced Eno's ambient aesthetic.
TD's sequencer-based long-form electronic music influenced Eno's ambient approach.
Kraftwerk's electronic methods and aesthetics influenced broader electronic music including Eno's work.
Schulze's long-form electronic works paralleled and influenced ambient aesthetics.
Plank's production approach—treating the studio as creative instrument—paralleled and influenced Eno's methods.
Switched-On Bach demonstrated synthesizer's musical potential, influencing German electronic musicians.
Hassell performed with Terry Riley in the late 1960s-1970s.
Contemporaries in New York minimalist/drone scene; both explored sustained tones and overtones.
Part of the same New York experimental scene exploring drones and sustained sounds.
Budd's quiet, sustained approach shares aesthetic with Feldman; influence acknowledged but extent debated.
Eno was founding member and synthesist for Roxy Music, developing his approach before going solo.
Fripp has been the only constant member and leader of King Crimson throughout its existence.
Schulze was founding drummer of Tangerine Dream, playing on Electronic Meditation.
Schnitzler was founding member of Tangerine Dream, playing on Electronic Meditation.
Franke was member during TD's most influential period.
Baumann was key member during TD's classic Phaedra and Rubycon period.
Schulze was founding drummer of Ash Ra Tempel before departing for solo career.
Schnitzler was founding member of Kluster (later Cluster) before departing.
Roedelius co-founded and remained member of Cluster.
Moebius co-founded and remained member of Cluster.
Roedelius was co-founder and member of Harmonia.
Moebius was co-founder and member of Harmonia.
Rother was co-founder and member of Harmonia.
Rother co-founded and was member of Neu!.
Dinger co-founded and was member of Neu!.
Hütter co-founded and has led Kraftwerk.
Schneider co-founded Kraftwerk and was member until 2008.
Young founded the Theatre of Eternal Music.
Conrad was key member of the Theatre of Eternal Music.
Hosono co-founded and was member of Yellow Magic Orchestra.
Sakamoto co-founded and was member of Yellow Magic Orchestra.
Eno founded Obscure Records to release experimental and ambient-adjacent work.
Baumann founded Private Music after leaving Tangerine Dream.
Schaeffer founded GRM (Groupe de Recherches Musicales).
Bayle directed GRM for over 30 years.
Oliveros was co-founder of San Francisco Tape Music Center.
Moog founded his company (initially R.A. Moog Co.).
Buchla founded Buchla and Associates.
Zinovieff co-founded EMS (Electronic Music Studios).
Cockerell co-founded EMS and designed VCS3 circuitry.
Cary co-founded EMS.
Schnitzler co-founded the Zodiak Free Arts Lab in Berlin.
Eno coined the term 'ambient music' and defined the movement with Music for Airports.
Schaeffer founded musique concrète with his first études.
Young is often credited as the first minimalist composer.
Riley's In C was foundational to the minimalist movement.
King Tubby pioneered dub music and mixing techniques.
Lee Scratch Perry was a co-pioneer of dub music.
Loriod studied with Martenot and became the foremost performer of the ondes Martenot. She taught at the Paris Conservatoire for 45 years.
Subotnick and Oliveros (along with Ramon Sender) co-founded the San Francisco Tape Music Center in 1962.
Subotnick commissioned Buchla to build the first Buchla synthesizer for the San Francisco Tape Music Center. They developed the instrument together.
Subotnick co-founded the San Francisco Tape Music Center.
Czukay studied with Stockhausen at the Cologne Courses for New Music, absorbing avant-garde techniques that influenced Can's experimental approach.
Czukay's tape manipulation, sampling techniques, and world music fusion on Canaxis 5 (1969) anticipated and influenced ambient production methods.
Czukay was co-founder and bassist of Can.
Ashikawa's Sound Process label released Yoshimura's Music for Nine Post Cards (1982). They were central figures in the kankyō ongaku movement.
Both were part of the early 1980s Japanese ambient/environmental music scene and contemporaries.
Contemporaries in the Japanese environmental music scene of the early 1980s.
Both part of the Japanese kankyō ongaku movement. Hosono's work for Muji paralleled the Sound Process aesthetic.
Ashikawa's environmental music concept was directly influenced by Eno's ambient philosophy, adapted for Japanese contexts.
Takada's Through the Looking Glass reflects ambient aesthetics of repetition and environmental sound, influenced by Western minimalism and ambient.
Aphex Twin's Selected Ambient Works series directly continues and develops Eno's ambient tradition.
The Orb's ambient house directly builds on Eno's ambient concepts. Paterson worked at EG Records (Eno's label) as A&R, giving him direct exposure to Eno's work.
Chill Out directly applies Eno's ambient philosophy—music for imaginary environments—to a conceptual road trip album.
Chill Out directly applies Eno's ambient philosophy to conceptual album format.
Perry collaborated with The Orb on Orbus Terrarum (1995), bringing dub production into ambient house.
Cauty and Paterson co-founded The Orb in 1988, collaborating on early tracks. Cauty left to focus on The KLF.
Drummond and Cauty founded The KLF (as The Justified Ancients of Mu Mu).
Both were key figures in the early 1990s UK electronic/ambient scene, part of same musical milieu.
Paterson founded The Orb with Jimmy Cauty.
Cauty co-founded The Orb before leaving to focus on The KLF.
Drummond co-founded The KLF.
Cauty co-founded The KLF.
Ashikawa founded the Sound Process label, the primary imprint for Japanese kankyō ongaku.
Derbyshire joined the BBC Radiophonic Workshop in 1962 and worked there until 1973, creating the iconic Doctor Who theme realization (1963) and hundreds of other electronic compositions.

Stockhausen began working at the WDR Studio for Electronic Music in Cologne in 1953, becoming its artistic director. He composed groundbreaking works there including Gesang der Jünglinge (1955-56) and Kontakte (1958-60).

Schaeffer established the musique concrète studio at French radio (RTF) in 1948, which evolved into GRM (Groupe de Recherches Musicales) in 1958. He directed the organization until Bayle succeeded him.
Henry joined Schaeffer's studio in 1949 as his primary collaborator, working at what would become GRM until departing to form his own studio in 1958.
Bayle joined GRM in 1960, became director in 1966 succeeding Schaeffer, and led the organization for over 30 years until 1997. He invented the Acousmonium speaker orchestra there.

Plank built his legendary studio in a converted farmhouse near Cologne in 1974. Nearly every important German electronic album was recorded there, including work by Kraftwerk, Cluster, Neu!, and collaborations with Eno.

Lanois built Grant Avenue Studio in Hamilton, Ontario with his brother Bob in the early 1970s. The studio's atmospheric production aesthetic, developed there, shaped ambient music. Eno visited and collaborated there in the early 1980s.

King Tubby built his studio at 18 Dromilly Avenue, Kingston in 1968. There he invented dub mixing techniques—extreme use of reverb, delay, and filtering—that became foundational to ambient production.
Perry built Black Ark Studio in his backyard in Kingston in 1973. The studio became legendary for experimental dub production until Perry allegedly burned it down in 1979.

Hütter and Schneider established Kling Klang Studio in Düsseldorf around 1970. The studio became Kraftwerk's private laboratory where they developed their distinctive electronic sound and custom instruments.
Schneider co-created Kling Klang with Hütter. He worked there developing custom electronic instruments and Kraftwerk's sound until his departure from the group.
Oliveros was a founding member and core composer at the San Francisco Tape Music Center from 1962-1966, developing her electronic composition practice and Deep Listening concepts there.
Subotnick co-founded and worked at the San Francisco Tape Music Center, commissioning the first Buchla synthesizer for the Center and composing Silver Apples of the Moon there.
Buchla developed his synthesizers in the San Francisco Bay Area, initially building the Buchla 100 series for the San Francisco Tape Music Center starting in 1963.
Young hosted Theatre of Eternal Music performances at his loft in New York, establishing it as a center for drone-based minimalist composition and performance.
Conrad performed regularly at Young's loft as a member of the Theatre of Eternal Music, developing his sustained violin drone techniques.
Young created the Dream House installation starting in 1969, a continuous sound and light environment that has been maintained at various locations, most notably at 275 Church Street in New York.
Russolo was based in Milan as a central figure of Italian Futurism. He built his intonarumori noise machines there and premiered them in Milan in 1913.
Schnitzler studied sculpture at the Düsseldorf Art Academy under Joseph Beuys in the early 1960s, absorbing Fluxus and conceptual art influences that shaped his experimental music approach.

Eno studied at Ipswich Art School (1964-66) and Winchester School of Art (1966-69), where he encountered cybernetics, systems thinking, and experimental composition that shaped his approach to ambient music.
Eno discovered Laraaji busking with his electric zither in Washington Square Park in 1979, leading to the production of Ambient 3: Day of Radiance.
Laraaji regularly busked in Washington Square Park in the late 1970s, playing his electric zither, where Eno discovered him in 1979.
Cage moved to New York City in 1942 and remained based there for the rest of his life. The city was central to his collaborations with the New York School composers and artists.
Feldman was born in New York City and remained based there throughout his career, central to the New York School avant-garde.
Reich moved to New York in 1965 and has been based there since, founding Steve Reich and Musicians and premiering major works at venues like The Kitchen.
Glass returned to New York in 1967 after studying in Paris and has been based there since, founding the Philip Glass Ensemble.
Reich performed at The Kitchen numerous times starting from its founding in 1971. The venue was crucial for premiering minimalist and experimental works.
Glass performed extensively at The Kitchen with the Philip Glass Ensemble throughout the 1970s.
Riley performed at The Kitchen multiple times in the 1970s as part of the minimalist movement's key performance venue.
Froese was born near Berlin and made it his base for Tangerine Dream. Berlin's isolation and unique cultural status shaped the 'Berlin School' electronic sound.
Schulze was born in Berlin and based his solo career there, becoming central to the Berlin School of electronic music.
Göttsching was born in Berlin and remained there throughout his career with Ash Ra Tempel and as a solo artist, recording E2-E4 in his Berlin studio.
Schnitzler moved to Berlin to establish the Zodiak Free Arts Lab in 1968 and remained central to the city's experimental scene.
Roedelius moved to Forst in the German countryside where Cluster and later Harmonia established their communal studio. Eno visited for his landmark 1976 sessions.
Moebius lived and worked in Forst with Roedelius, where Cluster developed their textural, atmospheric sound.
Rother joined Cluster in Forst to form Harmonia, commuting from Düsseldorf to record at their studio.
Eno visited Cluster and Harmonia at their Forst studio in 1976, recording sessions that produced Cluster & Eno and contributed to Tracks and Traces.
Hütter has been based in Düsseldorf throughout Kraftwerk's existence, establishing Kling Klang Studio there.
Schneider was born in Düsseldorf and remained there throughout his career with Kraftwerk.
Dinger was born in Düsseldorf and based Neu! there, developing the motorik beat that influenced post-punk and electronic music.
Rother was based in Düsseldorf during his time with Kraftwerk and Neu!, recording at Conny Plank's nearby studio.
Yoshimura was born in Tokyo and worked there creating environmental music for architectural and public spaces, including work with the Spiral building.
Hosono has been based in Tokyo throughout his career, founding Yellow Magic Orchestra there and creating kankyō ongaku for Muji stores.
Sakamoto was born in Tokyo and based his career there, co-founding Yellow Magic Orchestra and later creating ambient and film music.
Ashikawa was based in Tokyo where he founded Sound Process label and developed the theoretical framework for kankyō ongaku.
Takada has been based in Tokyo throughout her career as a percussionist and composer.
Satie lived in Paris and its suburbs (notably Arcueil) from 1887 until his death. He developed his furniture music concept there and was central to Parisian avant-garde circles.
Schaeffer was based in Paris working at French radio (RTF/ORTF), where he invented musique concrète and founded GRM.
Henry was born in Paris and worked there throughout his career, first at GRM and later at his own studio.
Martenot was born in Paris and developed the ondes Martenot there. He founded a school for the instrument at the Paris Conservatoire.
Loriod taught ondes Martenot at the Paris Conservatoire for 45 years and premiered major works in Paris.
Eno moved to London after art school and based his early career there with Roxy Music, Obscure Records, and his initial solo work.
Fripp has been based in London/UK throughout King Crimson's existence and his collaborations with Eno.
Zinovieff established his electronic music studio at his home in Putney, London, which became EMS headquarters where VCS3 and Synthi instruments were developed.
Cockerell designed the VCS3 circuitry at EMS's London studio, creating the instruments that became essential to British electronic music.
Cary was a founding partner of EMS, contributing his experience as a pioneering British electronic music composer.
Eno worked extensively at Hansa Studio in Berlin, producing David Bowie's Berlin Trilogy (Low, Heroes, Lodger) and his own collaborations.
Stockhausen attended the Darmstadt International Summer Courses for New Music starting in 1951, where he encountered serialism and later became a major teacher there.
Cage's legendary lectures at Darmstadt in 1958 introduced chance operations and influenced European avant-garde composers.
Tudor performed at Darmstadt in 1956 and subsequent years, premiering works by Cage, Feldman, and Stockhausen.
Young attended Darmstadt summer courses in 1959 where he encountered European avant-garde ideas that influenced his drone-based minimalism.
Riley attended Darmstadt in the early 1960s, encountering European experimental music before developing his tape loop and repetition techniques.
Ciani moved to San Francisco in the late 1960s and worked closely with Don Buchla, becoming the primary demonstrator of his instruments.
Riley was based in San Francisco during the development of In C (1964) and worked at the San Francisco Tape Music Center with La Monte Young's circle.
Moog was born in New York City and initially based his company in Trumansburg, NY, near Cornell where he studied. He demonstrated his instruments throughout New York.
Czukay moved to Cologne to study with Stockhausen and remained there, co-founding Can. He established Inner Space studio in a former cinema.
Stockhausen was based in Cologne from 1953, working at WDR and teaching at the Cologne Courses for New Music.
Richard D. James moved to London in 1991, becoming central to the city's electronic music scene and releasing on Warp Records.
Paterson has been based in London throughout his career, founding The Orb there and working at EG Records.
Drummond moved to London for his music career, co-founding The KLF there.
Cauty was based in London, co-founding both The KLF and The Orb there. His Trancentral studio was a key production location.
Cluster & Eno was recorded at Conny Plank's studio near Cologne, co-produced by Plank. The album exemplifies the studio's role in German/British ambient crossover.
After the Heat was recorded at Conny Plank's studio, continuing the Cluster & Eno collaboration with Plank engineering.
Neu!'s debut album was recorded at Conny Plank's studio. Plank's production was essential to capturing the motorik sound.
Neu! 75 was recorded at Conny Plank's studio, the final album in the band's trilogy.
Zuckerzeit was recorded at Conny Plank's studio. Plank's production helped Cluster develop their more accessible sound.
Sowiesoso was recorded at Conny Plank's studio. This pastoral album directly influenced Eno's ambient aesthetic.
Musik von Harmonia was recorded at Cluster's studio in Forst. Eno called Harmonia 'the world's most important rock band'.
The sessions that became Tracks and Traces were recorded during Eno's 1976 visit to Harmonia's studio in Forst.
Super Ape was recorded at Black Ark Studio, showcasing Lee Scratch Perry's innovative production techniques at their peak.
Dub from the Roots was mixed at King Tubby's studio, demonstrating his revolutionary approach to the mixing desk as instrument.
Music for Nine Post Cards was recorded in Tokyo and created for the Hara Museum of Contemporary Art's Air Pavilion space.
Watering a Flower was created in Tokyo as environmental music for Muji retail stores.
Through the Looking Glass was recorded in Tokyo, using traditional and ethnic percussion instruments.
Still Way was recorded in Tokyo on Ashikawa's Sound Process label.
Apollo: Atmospheres & Soundtracks was partially recorded at Daniel Lanois's Grant Avenue Studio in Hamilton, Ontario.
The Pearl was recorded at Grant Avenue Studio, co-produced by Lanois. His atmospheric production shaped the album's signature sound.
Switched-On Bach was recorded in New York using Moog synthesizers. Carlos and Moog collaborated on instrument development during the recording.
Silver Apples of the Moon was recorded on the Buchla synthesizer at the San Francisco Tape Music Center and completed at NYU.
Étude aux chemins de fer was created at the RTF studios in Paris (precursor to GRM), marking the birth of musique concrète.
Symphonie pour un homme seul was composed at Schaeffer's studio at RTF, the immediate precursor to GRM.
Gesang der Jünglinge was composed at the WDR Studio for Electronic Music in Cologne, using a combination of electronic sounds and processed voice.
Traité des objets musicaux was written while Schaeffer directed GRM, synthesizing his decades of musique concrète theory.
The Acousmonium spatial speaker system was developed by François Bayle at GRM, designed for immersive projection of acousmatic music.
Tangerine Dream was formed in Berlin and remained based there throughout their existence, defining the 'Berlin School' of electronic music.
Cluster relocated from Berlin to a rural commune in Forst in 1973, establishing their studio there.
Harmonia operated from Cluster's studio in Forst, where Eno visited in 1976.
Kraftwerk has been based at Kling Klang Studio in Düsseldorf since the early 1970s.
Kraftwerk was founded in Düsseldorf and has maintained their studio and headquarters there.
Neu! was formed in Düsseldorf by Rother and Dinger after they left Kraftwerk, recording at Conny Plank's nearby studio.
Ash Ra Tempel was founded and based in Berlin by Manuel Göttsching.
Yellow Magic Orchestra was formed and based in Tokyo, pioneering techno-pop there.
The Theatre of Eternal Music performed primarily at La Monte Young's loft in New York City.
The Theatre of Eternal Music performed at La Monte Young's loft, their primary venue.
The New York School of composers (Cage, Feldman, Tudor, etc.) was centered in New York City.
Roxy Music was formed and based in London.
King Crimson was formed and primarily based in London.
Eno founded Obscure Records in London to release experimental and ambient-adjacent music.
EMS (Electronic Music Studios) was founded and headquartered in London, initially at Zinovieff's home studio in Putney.
EMS operated from Zinovieff's home studio where VCS3 and Synthi instruments were developed.
GRM (the organization) operated from the GRM studio facilities in Paris.
GRM has been based in Paris since its founding as part of French radio.
The San Francisco Tape Music Center was located in San Francisco, initially at the San Francisco Conservatory.
The organization was based at the San Francisco Tape Music Center facilities.
Buchla and Associates was based in the San Francisco Bay Area, where Don Buchla developed his synthesizers.
Moog Music was initially based in New York State (Trumansburg, near Cornell University).
Can was formed in Cologne and established their Inner Space studio there, in a former cinema.
Faust was based in the Cologne area, initially working from a schoolhouse in Wümme converted to a studio.
Musique concrète was founded in Paris by Schaeffer at French radio studios.
While minimalism had roots in San Francisco, it became most associated with New York through Reich, Glass, and Riley's later work.
The Berlin School of electronic music was named for Berlin, where Tangerine Dream, Klaus Schulze, and Ash Ra Tempel were based.
Kankyō ongaku (Japanese environmental music) was centered in Tokyo, developed by Yoshimura, Hosono, and Ashikawa.
Dub music originated in Kingston, Jamaica, where King Tubby and Lee Scratch Perry developed the genre.
Italian Futurism was centered in Milan, where Marinetti published the first manifesto and Russolo built his intonarumori.
While spread across Germany, many key Krautrock bands (Can, Faust) and producer Conny Plank were based in or near Cologne.
Sound Process label was founded in Tokyo by Satoshi Ashikawa to release Japanese environmental music.
The Orb was formed in London and remained based there.
The KLF was based in London, operating from Jimmy Cauty's Trancentral studio.
The VCS3 synthesizer was developed at EMS's studio in Putney, London.
The Synthi AKS portable synthesizer was developed at EMS's London studio.
The Buchla 100 series was developed in San Francisco for the San Francisco Tape Music Center.
The Moog Modular synthesizer was developed in New York State (Trumansburg) by Robert Moog.
The Minimoog was developed at Moog Music in New York State.
While invented in Russia, the theremin was further developed and demonstrated by Theremin in New York from 1928.
The ondes Martenot was invented and developed by Maurice Martenot in Paris.
Russolo built his intonarumori noise machines in Milan as part of the Italian Futurist movement.
